annotation.TEXT: Maybe it's just me...but I can't help but feel that Wily Machine 4 tends to show up quite a bit in these fan-games. Either way, this incarnation of it isn't particularly difficult. The first phase fires shots directed towards you, while the second phase fires shots that travel across the floor. It also tries to drop explosives on you if you're underneath it, but you can easily avoid this if you keep sliding.
Dr. Wily's first two phases aren't really that notable, to be honest (especially since he's weak to both the Centaur Flash and Knight Crush).

And there we have Mega Man: Revenge of the Fallen. This one didn't take quite as long to complete as I initially thought (at least in terms of segments, anyways). I mostly blame my inability to consistently upload these parts on real life shenanigans, but either way, I'm glad I managed to see it through.

Granted, I wouldn't say this game is Mega Man Unlimited levels of difficulty, but it can certainly be up there at times. It can take a lot of time and preparation to get used to it, but for what it's worth, this game does have some pretty enjoyable moments in it.

The floor is supposed to break open once you beat Wily Machine 5, but it seems like the trigger to make this happen only goes off if you're on the left side of the screen. I didn't realize this at first, and for a moment I thought the game had glitched (but thankfully that wasn't the case).

Phase 2 also has an extra attack where the machine will lower itself to the floor a bit, then fire out a large laser that you need to jump over (it's mostly comparable to Sunstar's laser attack from MMV). If you're using his weakness however, you can potentially take him down before he even gets the chance to use it.

To be honest, I haven't even encountered half of the possible Robot Master combinations this phase can send out. From what I've heard, Jewel Man and Plug Man is one of the rarer combos that not many seem to encounter (at least in terms of recorded playthroughs anyways).

The most important thing to note on however is this game's difficulty. Even though it might not look like it at times, this game can be very hard to get through (even on the normal difficulty setting). If you're not that good at Mega Man games, I wouldn't really recommend diving into this one without building up some experience with the official games or with some of the easier fan-games out there.

Overall, I'd say this is somewhere in the middle grounds of my fan-game list. It's not the best one I've played (that would probably go to either Rock Force or Rokko-Chan), but it still stands out on its own regards. If you're looking for a difficult fan-game (that isn't Unlimited), I'd say give this one a go. Just be prepared to either die a lot or use the cheat code to pick up your progress in Wily's fortress (unless you plan on completing it in a single run).
What's that? Mega Man Scramble? Never heard of it before.

The thrid phase, on the other hand, is where things get more interesting. Aside from the usual Wily Capsule projectiles, he can also send out shadow clones of various Robot Masters. There's actually a multitude of different sets that can appear in this fight (nearly 4 Robot Masters from almost each entry in the classic series - with the exception of MM8 - all of which attack in pairs of 2, usually with those related to weakness orders in some way).

So then, now we're being chased by Wily Machine 5. You can't damage it (yet), so the only thing you can do for now is run and try not to get crushed to death. There's a few enemies and hazards to give you a harder time during this, the most notable of which are the Rolling Drills from Napalm Man's stage. They still kill you instantly if you run into them, but you can't stand on top of them anymore.

Now then, my overall thoughts on the game itself: This game might not have an abundance of custom assets that most other fan-games possess, but there's still some pretty interesting things on display here, especially when it comes to modifying some of the pre-existing gimmicks or weapons.

It's also worth noting that there's a secret on the upper path you can reach by getting above the ceiling (this can be done with either Tornado Blow or Yamato Spear). This leads to a secret area with several E, W, and M-Tanks, along with a teleporter that goes directly to the final boss.

I'm honestly not too sure how I feel about the increased level length and branching paths, though. I don't mind the concept of them in general, but sometimes the stages do feel like they're overstaying their welcome (Stone Man and Star Man's stages in particular being the most guilty of this).

As I've stated before, I'm not a huge fan of most MIDI music (keyword being most). With that being said, Wily 7's music is easily my favorite tune in the whole game. The tone itself is a nice change of pace when compared to most of the other tracks.
